I will test and merge this, @markusweimer .  :)

I believe much of this class (if not all of it) could be deprecated, as it should never have been `public` in the first place and much of it isn't used in the new code paths.

True?
This looks good. I will merge.
This looks good. +1 on merging. However, I am not setup to do the testing right now. Any volunteers?
@bgchun Can you have a look at this?

@jwang98052 @tcNickolas

Sure

Yep. It's done now, @dkm2110 .
This looks good enough to merge. I'll test and merge.
@dongjoon-hyun Using `put` in ConcurrentMap is not thread safe. We need to use `putIfAbsent` and `replace` instead. Let's close this one without merging it.
I will review and test
Looks good. I will merge it.

@markusweimer  @jwang98052 

This is the pull request for creating IPartitionedOutput dataset. Please review.
@jwang98052 I've done a pass.

I don't understand the use case for this code. For instance, the driver side here is assumed to statically know the number of partitions for the output as well as their ID. How can this be true in the general case? For instance, if someone were to use these classes in a MapReduce engine, how would they determine the number of reducers and their ids upfront without ever looking at the data?
@anupam128 +1 on merging. However, I am not able to test right now and we'd need a volunteer for it.
Review comments are addressed and pushed in.
Looks good....I will test and merge

@jwang98052 

None of IO.TestClient functions run on Hadoop clusters. I tried two of them...The problem is that vol1 path that you are giving is specific to some cluster that you are trying on and not generic one. Perhaps ask user to give input the filename?
Moreover it would be good to test on two different clusters before sending another review

The following changes have been made:
*For remote file copy test, passing remote file name from command line instead of hard coding in the test
*For file path used in the test, use /tmp/xxx which is generic in any environment
*All the tests have been passed in the YARN environment we are currently testing. 
*However, none of them work on HDI cluster. With the fix in the relative path, It doesn't look at path issue. I am not sure if we ever run Hadoop file system tests in REEF.IO.Tests in HDI cluster before since it was created. We should create a separate Jira to track it. 
The changes have been pushed.

> For remote file copy test, passing remote file name from command line instead of hard coding in the test

This makes it hard to automate the test, right? As we would now have to somehow supply the command line parameter to the test.

> For file path used in the test, use /tmp/xxx which is generic in any environment

Source? Is `/tmp` universally agreed upon by HDFS clusters?

@markusweimer regarding test automation, it is currently standalone application and not test. So shud be ok.

Also I looked online, /tmp should be present on Hadoop clusters

@markusweimer @jwang98052 

given tests do not pass on HDI as Julia said, shud we wait or merge this?
Not passing HDI testing is not introduced by the change in this PR. We should have a separate Jira to follow it up to ensure all REEF.IO.Tests pass in HDI.
All tests pass on Hadoop cluster

@markusweimer  @jwang98052     

When trying to merge I got permission issues

C:\Users\dhrumaha\Desktop\incubator-reef\lang\cs [master]> git push origin master
remote: Permission to apache/incubator-reef.git denied to dkm2110.

What do I need to do?
@markusweimer @tcNickolas I will test and merge after you sign off. Thanks!
@anupam128 @markusweimer I'll test and merge this today. Thanks!
@markusweimer I just checked in the ASA codebase, and ASA is using the functions `GetAssembliesListForReefDriverApp`, `CopyDllsToAppDirectory`, and `GenerateClassHierarchy`.
My interest was limited to Findbug violations, which have been fixed. Current check failures are unrelated to it (and should be fixed one this is merged with master which has the fix). I sign off
@jwang98052  I have done the review. Some minor comments.

I just talked with @jwang98052, it seems like `GenerateClassHierarchy` is no longer needed, so I will deprecate that. As to the other two calls, I believe they may still be helpful in some contexts. I'll send out an email to the dev board as well.

@markusweimer Isn't it the case with InputDataset also?

But I see the problem you are talking about. You are saying that the FIlesystemOutputDataset cannot be general entry point for output and I agree. But we still need IOutputPartition or do you think even that is not needed?
@dkm2110 I have addressed review comments and the change has been pushed in. Please review/merge.
@dkm2110  Review comments addressed.
I will test and merge
merged
I rebased and changed the code and JIRA according your comments. Thank you again.
@dongjoon-hyun Looks good. I will test and merge.
@tcNickolas . It looks good to me. I'll test and merge.
Hi, @tcNickolas . It's merged. Now, you can publish the website.

> Isn't it the case with InputDataset also?

The Driver can introspect the files on HDFS to decide how many partitions there are. For the output, we sometimes can't know this upfront. As I said on the JIRA, we might be well advised to look at some of the prior art here to make sure the design is sane.

> But we still need IOutputPartition or do you think even that is not needed?

We need something there, of course. But how to do it is less obvious. For instance, Hadoop has an `OutputCollector` which receives one record at a time. That allows the system to be in charge of the allocations. However, we might want to be more generic than records.

I've done a pass and it left me confused. The API suggests that the application state is somehow mutable from the Client side. Also, the example code now sets it? Wouldn't the status of an application be read-only from the client? And not set by application code, but instead provided by REEF?
@beysims has done lots of work in this area.

@markusweimer  @beysims 

It seems currently we do not have enough time and resources for this and it seems that I am not the right person to take lead on the design. So I am leaving it for now and lighting up output in IMrectly via REEF-576. We will visit it later then.
I'll do a pass.

This looks good to me. Reading through the JIRA discussion, it seems like you and @markusweimer still have some unresolved issues with regards to transition of the `SUSPEND` value, so I'll wait for him to sign off as well to test and merge. Thanks!
This looks good, I'll test and merge. Thanks!
Thank you, @afchung .
I am looking into this as well
Review comments are addressed and the change checked in.
@markusweimer  I have made changes per your review and pushed. Please have a look.
I will review it.
I will look at it again.
@markusweimer Could you please have a look at the request?
I completed my pass
I've done another pass.

@jwang98052 We aren't blocked on reviews here, we need to do some more design work. 

@dkm2110 Can you close this PR and we can do the design over on JIRA?
@afchung , it looks good to me. I'll test and merge.
Indeed, it seems more natural for wait time to increase linearly with the number of retries than to behave in a quadratic way, so log message seems more proper. I'll test and merge
It looks good to me. I will test and merge.
addressed review comments and pushed in the change.

@jwang98052  I have incorporated the review comments
@markusweimer I have reintroduced ResultHandler since I fell IObserver<T> might be too general as Julia commented.
It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
@markusweimer  Updated.
@beysims @jwang98052 please have a look when you have time. Thanks!
You can still use IObserver if you would like, but the T needs to be specific, like use you defined interface instead of int or something.

I see..anyways I have changed it to interface. I think its fine.

Dhruv

On Fri, Oct 30, 2015 at 10:10 AM, Julia Wang notifications@github.com
wrote:

> You can still use IObserver if you would like, but the T needs to be
> specific, like use you defined interface instead of int or something.
> 
> —

> .
@markusweimer Updated with your comments. Thanks!

I've done a pass. There are a couple minor comments not worth doing an extra iteration over them; I'll fix them and merge.
Thank you for doing this! We're one step closer to closing REEF-519

P.S. I still don't understand why DiamondOperatorForVariableDefinition doesn't catch places where diamond operator can be used.
It would appear that some tests are unstable with this PR, I'll take a closer look...

Can the reviewer pull and run tests on Local? I don't believe my changes should affect the tests that are run in the Jenkins environment. I was not able to repro the previous Jenkins failures on my Windows box. Thanks!

Thank you, @tcNickolas . Initially, I tried to finish REEF-519, but it's difficult due to TODOs.

For the your last question, Wake's pom.xml file does not have `maven-checkstyle-plugin`. So, Check-Style is turned off for Wake module. I found several other modules also were.

What about having a new rule without TODO check? 
`lang/java/reef-common/src/main/resources/checkstyle-strict-without-TODO.xml`

Checkstyle in general is enabled for modules which don't have `maven-checkstyle-plugin` in their pom.xml. Its configuration is inherited from `reef-project`'s pom file. Just try to violate some check from standard set of checks, for example, add a line over 120 characters long to one of the files in Wake, and it will dutifully fail build due to checkstyle violation. `maven-checkstyle-plugin` is present in subprojects which are using `checkstyle-strict.xml` configuration instead of standard one, but it contains `DiamondOperatorForVariableDefinition`. However, there might be some weird configuration issue related to use of check which is not part of standard checks set.

I don't really like cloning checkstyle settings for each combination of issues we've fixed, as this makes adding new checks harder. I hope to be able to triage some more TODOs next week. For Wake project, we need to summon @bgchun to help triage https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-535.
Yep. I agree with you. The best way is to resolve REEF-535, and eventually all sub-issues of REEF-519.
@afchung , I tested and it passed, too.
Thanks @dongjoon-hyun!
I completed my pass with only a couple of comments.
Hi, @gyeongin . It looks good to me. I'll merge this.
Hi, @afchung . It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
I'll merge this.
I'll merge.
I'm not sure about this change. This parameter only makes sense on the YARN runtime, after all. It is in the wrong package, though.

Oh, then, may I change that package name according to the directory path like the following?

```
package org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.parameters;
```

I guessed that the reason of package naming was both `reef-runtime-yarn` and `reef-runtime-hdinsight` use that.
This is tricky, as the class is `public`. We might have to do a whole round of deprecation / renaming.

I agree the name change, make them readable: 
Change SubmitAndGetDriverUrl to SubmitAndGetJobStatus
change IDriverHttpEndpoint to IDriverHandle
SubmitAndGetJobStatus returns IDriverHandle just like SubmitAndGetDriverUrl  returns IDriverHttpEndpoint 

Inside IDriverHandle, DriverUri and AppId are unchanged once the Job is submitted. Client gets IDriverHandle  after calling SubmitAndGetDriverUrl. I am not sure if we want to expose IDriverHandle in IREEFClient for the caller of the REEFClient to get the handle again. Because what the client really needs to call again is GetStatus,as it may change while the Job is executing.
I see.

I will test and merge if there is not objection. This is to unlock the current work in IMRU.
We will come out long term resolution and replace this change.
